definition:
The conservation status of a
group of organisms (for instance, a species) indicates whether the group still
exists and how likely the group is to become extinct in the near future.
[Wikipedia]
opposite_reasoning: Abundance provides the strongest semantic opposition for Fisher-LDA purposes. ConservationStatus fundamentally tracks the concern about population scarcity/endangerment, while Abundance represents plentiful, thriving populations. This creates a clear bipolar axis (scarce/threatened ↔ abundant/secure) that is conceptually clean and likely well-represented in embedding spaces. While 'Extinction' is tempting as the terminal state, it's more of an endpoint than an opposite status. Abundance better captures the positive pole of the conservation spectrum and is more likely to have rich semantic associations in text corpora (abundant wildlife, thriving populations, etc.) that will create useful Fisher-LDA separation.
